Overwhelming Information Overload: With the ability to remember everything they read, humans would be inundated with information, leading to an overwhelming information overload. People would struggle to process and make sense of all the data they had collected, leading to a loss of focus and productivity.

Lack of Originality: If everyone could remember everything they read, there would be a decrease in originality as people would rely too heavily on existing knowledge rather than coming up with their own ideas. This could stifle creativity and innovation, leading to a lack of progress in many fields.

Privacy Concerns: The ability to remember everything read could also lead to privacy concerns, as individuals would be able to recall sensitive information they had read or heard about others. This could lead to unintended consequences such as the spread of gossip or the misuse of personal information.

Increased Empathy: On the other hand, the ability to remember everything read could also increase empathy, as people would be able to better understand and relate to the experiences of others. This could lead to a more compassionate and understanding society.

Lack of Concentration: With the ability to remember everything they read, people would no longer need to focus on reading, leading to a lack of concentration and a decrease in the quality of their work. This could be particularly problematic in fields such as medicine or law, where attention to detail is critical.
